body:
> Would it be possible to add another flag to not fail the script in such scenarios where a dev fixes a violation but not update the eslint-suppressions.json file?

Can you explain more about what this means to you?

I'm assuming what you're after is allowing someone to submit a PR with their changes without CI failing?

More details and an example scenario would be helpful to understand what it is you're looking for.

Yes, exactly that. A very small team owns and controls all the ESLint config files. Which means that if a dev wants to commit a code after hours or in a different timezone, they can't do so till they get approvals from that small team that owns the ESLint config files (such as `eslint.config.js`, `eslint-suppressions.json`, custom configs or overrides files).
We could exempt `eslint-suppressions.json` file from this ownership, but it will open up the gates for anyone to keep adding new entries in this file instead of only deleting old entries in the file.
So what we would want is let devs commit their PRs without the CI failing and without mandating the need to update the `eslint-suppressions.json` file should they intentionally/unintentionally fix an ESLint rule violation.

Thanks for explaining. So it sounds like what you want is a way to exit with a 0 error code even when there are unpruned suppressions?

So basically, when you see this message:

> There are suppressions left that do not occur anymore. Consider re-running the command with `--prune-suppressions`.

We exit with code 0 instead of 2.

So I think this raises an interesting question: Would it make more sense for this to be a warning instead of an error? Or would it make sense to add an option to toggle it to a warning?

@eslint/eslint-tsc @softius what do you think?

Yes, it should exit with error code 0 instead of 2. I mentioned the same thing in the original discussion(#19677) and #19698 merged to fix the docs, because the earlier doc made me think it is just a warning and not an error.

The rationale for a non-zero exit code was that leaving unused suppressions can be dangerous because it allows new violations to be introduced after old ones are fixed:

https://github.com/eslint/rfcs/tree/main/designs/2024-baseline-support#maintaining-a-lean-suppressions-file

I think this should remain the default behavior, but I'm not against adding an option to toggle it to a warning.

I believe this needs to be an error . Leaving the suppressions file un-pruned for a long time is a risk, and eventually it will open the door for new errors to go unnoticed.

For example developer A addresses ten violations from file `foobar.js`. Then this is merged into `main` without updating the suppressions file. As a result, other developers can introduce ten new violations for the same rule , same file without any error. 

Given the use case provided here, another option would be to exit with a dedicated exit code i.e. `3` instead of `2` so that it can be ignored when needed. But I feel a new option would be closer to the existing eslint functionality.

Okay, sounds like an option would be the way to go. @softius your idea of a dedicated exit code is interesting. What if the new option just let you set the exit code? Something like `--unpruned-suppressions-exit-code`? That would allow people to set to `0` if they wanted, but also to `11` if they wanted to know for sure why ESLint exited.

@nzakas that feels a bit unusual, at least for my taste :) 

I can see that eslint exists with `1` where there are reported errors and `2` for everything else, so the idea was a new exit code for  unmatched suppressions. Also, it seems that `2` was not the right exit code anyway as it suggests that the lint was not successful.

For reference: https://eslint.org/docs/latest/use/command-line-interface#exit-codes

Currently,  unpruned suppressions exit with code 2, which seems appropriate in that it's not a linting violation. It seems there's agreement that there should be some way to change this exit code to 0. My thinking is that another use case might be to setup CI to be able to detect unpruned suppressions, in which case we'd need a way to not just change the exit code to 0 but also to something else.

Otherwise it seems like we'd need something like `--pass-on-unpruned-suppressions` to set exit code to 0. If we think there's never a situation where we want an exit code outside of 0 and 2, that's okay. If we think there's also a chance we'd want to have a different exit code, then I think something like `--unpruned-suppressions-exit-code` makes more sense.

How about doing `--pass-on-unpruned-suppressions` as you described @nzakas , but also change the exit code outside of 0 and 2?

This way we give a straightforward option to skip checking for unpruned suppressions. We also cater for special cases where we can catch the dedicated exit code to do more complicated stuff i.e. leaving a comment on the PR when there are unpruned suppressions, before marking the build as failed.

I think having a dynamic exit code makes things a bit more complicated without adding significant value, unless I am missing something of course.

> How about doing `--pass-on-unpruned-suppressions` as you described [@nzakas](https://github.com/nzakas) , but also change the exit code outside of 0 and 2?

The goal here is to make CI pass when there are unpruned suppressions, so the only real option is to set the exit code to 0. Changing it to something else means they'd have to implement special logic in their CI to handle this case.

And this is my point: I can see a situation where some people want a 0 exit code for this purpose while others might want to specifically detect unprune suppressions, in which case an option to set the exit code is preferable over one that just sets it back to 0.

I see your point @nzakas , and I think we are aligned on the options we want to provide :) 

Let me expand a bit more: if we change the `return 2` to `return 3` when there are unpruned suggestions and keep it dedicated just for this case - then we don't need to introduce `--unpruned-suppressions-exit-code`.

People that want to ignore unpruned suppressions can go with the simple `--pass-on-unpruned-suppressions`, instead of `--unpruned-suppressions-exit-code 0`.

People that want to handle unpruned suppressions differently can check the exit code and perform the corresponding action without the need to specify `--unpruned-suppressions-exit-code 3` or whatever exit code they decide to go with (since elsint will always exit with exit code 3 for unpruned suppressions)

I think allowing to choose the exit code might lead to conflicts later on . For example, someone decides to do `--unpruned-suppressions-exit-code 3` and few months down the road eslint also introduces exit code 3.
